Title: Prove a Levi-Civita connection gives $\nabla_XY(p)=\partial_t|_{t_0}[P^{-1}_{c_0,t_0,t}(Y(c(t)))]$ with $P$ parallel transport
Content:
I'm having trouble with the following exercise in do Carmo's Riemannian geometry. Let $X$ and $Y$ be differentiable vector fields on a Riemannian manifold $M$. Let $p \in M$ and let $c: I 	o M$ be an integral curve of $X$ through $p$, i.e. $c(t_0) = p$ and $ rac{dc}{dt} = X(c(t))$. 
Prove that the Riemannian connection of $M$ is $(
abla_XY \ )(p) =  rac{d}{dt} (P^{-1}_{c,t_0,t}(Y(c(t)))\ |_{t=t_0}$ where $P^{-1}_{c,t_0,t}: T_{c(t_0)}M 	o T_{c(t)}M$ is the parallel transport along $c$, from $t_0$ to $t$. I guess, I don't have enough understanding of how to handle the parallel transport (since it is only given as the unique solution to a differential equation). Any hints would be greatly appreciated! Thank you,
S. L. Edit: Do Carmo first introduced the notion of an affine connection $
abla: 	ext{Vect}(M) 	imes 	ext{Vect}(M) 	o 	ext{Vect}(M)$,   $(X,Y) \mapsto 
abla_XY$. With the following properties: $
abla_{fX + gY}Z = f
abla_XZ + g 
abla_YZ$ $
abla_X(Y+Z) = 
abla_XY + 
abla_XZ$ $
abla_X(fY) = f
abla_XY + X(f)Y$ for $X,Y,Z \in 	ext{Vect}(M)$ and $f,g \in C^\infty(M)$. And then showed that there is a unique correspondence which associates to a vector field $V$ along the differentiable curve $c: I 	o M$ another vector field $ rac{DV}{dt}$ along c, called covariant derivative of $V$ along $c$, with three more properties: $ rac{D}{dt}(V+W) =   rac{D}{dt}V +   rac{D}{dt}W$ $  rac{D}{dt}(fV) =   rac{df}{dt}V +  f rac{D}{dt}V$ If $V$ is induced by a vector field $Y \in 	ext{Vect}(M), then   rac{D}{dt}V = 
abla_{dc/dt}Y$ Then he showed existence and uniqueness of the parallel transport along a curve, and went on to prove existence and uniqueness of Levi-Civita connection. I hope this makes things clearer? Thanks for the quick answer!
AcceptedAnswer:
Let $\{e_i\}\subseteq T_{c(t_0)}M$ be a basis.  Define $E_i(t)$ as the parallel translation of $e_i$ along $c(t)$.  Prove to yourself that $\{E_i(t)\}$ forms a basis of $T_{c(t)}$ for all $t$ (hint, use the uniqueness part of solving linear ODEs). Now, we can write $Y(c(t)) = \sum_i a_i(t) E_i(t)$.  Then, since the $E_i(t)$ are parallel, and since $P_{c,t_0,t}$ is linear, we have $P^{-1}_{c,t_0, t}(Y(c(t)) = \sum_i a_i(t) e_i$. From here, by actually computing the limit, it's not too hard to see that $ rac{d}{dt} P^{-1}_{c,t_o,t}Y(c(t))|_{t=t_0} = \sum_i a_i'(t_0)e_i$. Thus, the goal is to show that $
abla_X Y(p)$ can also be written like this. But $
abla_X Y(p) = 
abla_X \sum_i a_i(t)E_i(t)|_{t=t_0} = \sum_i a_i(t_0) 
abla_X E_i(t)|_{t=t_0} + \sum_i a_i'(t_0) E_i(t_0)$.  (The second equality is just the Leibniz rule every connection must satisfy).  However, $
abla_X E_i(t)$ is $ rac{D}{dt} E_i(t)$ and this is 0 since the $E_i$ are parallel.  Hence, the first term of the sum vanishes, so we get the desired result.
